p.s: As I already said this political speech, which was given by the British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on the COP26, which is the global climate change conferenzconference werewhere all the leaders of the nations of the world come together, is about the climate crisis and role of the COP26.
The speech was given on the occasion of the COP26 and off courseof course also because of the rapitelyrapidly continueingcontinuing of climate change.
The audience of the speech are obviously the leaders of the countries of the world, because Johnson gives his speech in front of them.
But the speech is also addressed to all the people in the world, who can hear the speech with radio or television.

In this speech, Boris Johnson tries to draw a convincing picture of the dangers and to give his audience hope and encourage them to take action, by comparing the whole situation with a James Bond movie.

Just in the beginning of his speech Johnson claims that climate change is real a danger for mankind and that we have to find a solution for it, by comparing the whole situation with the James Bond movie (cf. l. 6).

He says that every James Bond movie has doomsday device (l. 3) and James Bond is the man who has to save the whole world by finding the right colored wire to turn turn the doomsday device ofoff, while the clock for the end of the world is ticking (cf. l. 5).

So in this metaphor of Johnson the doomsday device (l. 3) is the climate change, which puts a risk on the whole mankind and the audience of Johnson speech, so the leaders of the COP26, are James Bond and have to find the right colored wire so the solution to stop the climate change and to save the world, while the clock is ticking, because climate change is already happending (cf. l. 3).

This metaphorametaphor shows the danger of climate change for the mankind, so that it could destroy everything and it also underlines the duty of the leaders of COP26 to act now like James Bond and to save the world.
After that comparison Boris Johnson shows that nothing happened by now, although it is obvious that there is a real problem, by the anaphora I was there... (l. 10, 11).
This anaphora shows that the conferences in Copenhagen or in Paris were just blah blah blah (l. 13) and nothing changed over the years.
So COP26 has to be the part werewhere this changes, as Johnson says.
In the next paragraph, Johnson stresses that we are able to solve the problem and that we have the remedies for it.
He underlines that with the repetition of We can (l. 16) and enumeration (cf. l. 16) which shows that we are able to solve all the problems that come within climate change.
After that, Johnson makemakes clear that industrialized countries have the duty to help the other countries as they created the climate change.

But he says that this financial help cannot be enough if just the governments are spending (cf. l. 22), so he wants the market and the private sector to also help, by e.g. investigating in screen technology (cf. ll. 23).
To underline how important this is, he makes clear that only the private sector made the brithishBritish independence from coal possible.

He describes the UK as the Saudi Arabia of wind (l. 29), which is a metaphor and also and antithesis, because Saudi-Arabia is very rich by there large deposits of oilm which is in contrast to the green technology that the wind stands for.
This metaphor underlines the independence of the UK from coal or oil, so they do not need Saudi-Arabia anymore.
In the following he points out, that the people who will suffer the climate change, or not the people who live now on the planet, but the posterity (l. 39).

To underlinesunderline that he repeadsrepeats the word children (l. 38), which also stands for the innocenseinnocence of the following generations as thethey did not create the climate change, but they have to suffer.
Johnson also wants to play to sympathy for the following generations by this.
So Johnson comes to the conclusion that we have to act for the praprity that we have the duty to do something as we are able to stop it (cf. ll. 45).
He underlines it by the anaphora We have (l. 46) to show that we are able to solve this problem so we have the duty to do it.
At the end Johnson comes back to his comparison with James Bond from the beginning.
He says although they won't feel or even look like James Bond, they have to act like him.
By that he underlines aggainagain the duty but also a little bit the honour to save the world, like James Bond does it every time.
So Johnson appeals to the audience to begin to act and to fight against the climate change (cf. ll. 49).

To put it in a nutshell Johnson appeals to fight against the climate change, as it is a real danger and is already happening and that we have the remedies and the duty to something not just for us, but also for the following generations.
He tries this by the comparison with James Bond, to show that it's even possible, as James Bond is also able to save the world every time.
